Introduction

A comprehensive understanding of breast anatomy is required for clinical practice, especially in the fields of surgery, oncology, and radiology.  The breast is a dynamic organ involved in lactation and hormonal responses.

Breast development



In utero, the breasts develop from the mammary ridge (milk line), an ectodermal thickening that initially extends bilaterally from the axillae to the medial thighs; the remainder of the ridge subsequently regresses in early gestation.



Occasionally, incomplete involution of the mammary ridge results in the formation of an accessory nipple (sometimes with associated glandular tissue) anywhere along this ridge (

figure 1
).  The most common location of an accessory nipple is inferior to the breast.  Accessory nipples are usually asymptomatic, well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented papules that may become larger during puberty, before menses, or with pregnancy/lactation due to rising estrogen and progesterone levels (similar to physiologic changes in normal breast tissue).  Associated glandular tissue may also become tender or swollen.

Puberty



At birth, the breast rudiment contains 10-12 primitive glandular structures located beneath the nipple/areolar complex.  Prior to puberty, these ducts have very slow growth and branching.  For males, breast development halts at this stage.  For females, puberty marks the beginning of breast maturation (ie, thelarche) with an increase in stromal tissue and glandular development: The ducts proliferate and divide to form terminal end buds, which are transient structures that ultimately branch into small ductules called alveolar buds.  With further maturation and hormonal stimulation throughout the menstrual cycle (eg, via progesterone, estrogen), alveolar buds differentiate into the acinus, the terminal structure of the resting breast.  However, the breast does not reach full differentiation until pregnancy/lactation occurs.

Pregnancy



During pregnancy, additional branching occurs during the first trimester, and maximum glandular formation (ie, an increase in acini per terminal duct) and differentiation occur during the second and third trimesters.  The full extent of glandular differentiation is achieved with the formation of the secretory acinus, which is characterized by the ability to secrete milk proteins (caseins) and lipids.

Breast structure



The adult breast is located in the superficial fascia of the anterior thoracic wall and is supported by suspensory ligaments (eg, Cooper ligaments).  It extends vertically from the 2nd rib to the 6th rib and laterally from the sternum to the midaxillary line.  The nipple is located centrally on the breast and is surrounded by the pigmented areola.



The breast is composed of both stromal and epithelial tissue (

figure 2
).  The stroma consists of fibrous connective tissue and adipose tissue and constitutes the majority of breast volume in nonlactating adult women.  Each breast is arranged into 15-20 lobes that radiate from the nipple, with intervening stromal tissue.  The lobes drain into a major lactiferous duct that converges into a lactiferous sinus beneath the areola to drain at the nipple.  Each lobe is further subdivided into lobules, which are composed of branched alveolar glands.  The structural and functional unit of the breast is the terminal duct lobular unit, each of which comprises the distal smallest duct (terminal duct) and the attached acini (mature alveolar glands).

Histology



The entire ductal and lobular system of the breast is lined by 2 cell types.  The luminal aspect of the duct and acini contains columnar or cuboidal cells, whereas the outer cell layer is composed of spindle-shaped myoepithelial cells, which reside above the basement membrane.  The contractile myoepithelial cells are responsive to oxytocin and aid in milk ejection.

Blood supply



The primary blood supply of the breast is the internal mammary artery (or internal thoracic artery), which originates from the subclavian artery.  Additional supply is through the lateral thoracic artery (also known as the external mammary artery), a branch of the axillary artery, which supplies primarily the upper, outer quadrants of the breast.  Venous drainage occurs primarily through the axillary vein.

Lymphatic drainage



Lymphatic drainage occurs through both superficial and deep lymphatic vessels.  Lymph flows unidirectionally from the superficial system to the deep plexus.  Most of the lymph flow of the breasts drains to the axillary lymph nodes (

figure 3
), although some can be directed to other nodes (eg, internal mammary nodes receive drainage medially, clavicular nodes receive drainage from the upper, outer quadrants of the breast).  Sampling of the lymphatic drainage of the breast helps determine metastatic spread of breast cancer.

Innervation



The innervation of the breast comes primarily from the third, fourth, and fifth intercostal nerves.  The nipple receives highly concentrated innervation from the fourth intercostal nerve and typically lies at the level of the T4 dermatome.
